column2: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 25-- Byron Nelson's torrid golfing tools chilled today and Ben Hogan caught fire to set the stage for a rousing Sunday finish in the Knoxville open tournament.
NON-THEATRICAL motion picture production and exhibition, which expanded tremendously throughout, the world during the war, is expected to become even more widespread in the next several years.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP)--The enemy's Singapore radio said today Japanese forces had ceased all operational activity at that naval base, but that peaceful surrender negotiations "will be extremely difficult to carry out in the face of subversive conduct on the part...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Arthur S. Fleming, a member of the United States Civil Service Commission, invited veterans tonight to seek positions in the Federal Government and promised that the spirit, as well as the letter, of the Veterans Preference Act would be observed.

LONDON, Aug. 25--Britain's recently elected Labor Government faced up to the task of reconversion this week, acutely conscious of that fact that the British public's patience over controls and scarcities is wearing thin after almost six years of war.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP)--Britain's "Foreign Office commentator" isn't talking any more. Neither is the "Foreign Office spokesman."

MARSEILLE, Aug. 25 (AP)-- Seven thousand Negro troops will be leaving here within the next few days for the United States, where they will be demobilized, Maj. Daniel J. Brady of Newmarket, N. H., port liaison officer, said today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (AP)-- Miss Ann Curtis began her bid for another quadruple swimming championship by defeating Miss Brenda Helser and a strong field in the 100-meter free style event last night as the National A.A.U. senior women's meet opened.
ONE of the season's more provocative events--and there may be a touch of understatement in that--should be Henry Holt's publication, on Sept. 13, of "The German Talks Back," by Heinrich Hauser.
NYACK, N. Y., Aug. 25--John B. Karkos, founder of the Nyack Junior School, has purchased the estate of the late Bozo Banac, Yugoslav shipping magnate, from his widow, Mrs. Milicia Banac.

MANILA, Sunday, Aug 26 (Reuter)--Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York is expected to arrive at Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters here today by plane. Archbishop Spellman has recently been visiting Guam.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP)-- The Braves snapped a five-game Philadelphia winning streak when they defeated the Phils, 5--3, in the first game of a scheduled twinight double-header here before 18,500 fans. A heavy shower halted the second game after two innings had been played.

RICHMOND, Aug. 25--Department store sales in the Fifth Reserve District were curtailed by the surrender holidays and the week ended Aug. 18 showed a decline of 2 per cent from the corresponding 1944 week. For four weeks,
VIENNA, Aug. 25-Of the 206,000 Jews who lived in Austria when Germany annexed it in 1938 only 6,900 now remain. This number includes some 1,500 who have...

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)--The American Newspaper Guild's executive board tonight rescinded its wartime "no strike pledge" and voted to place the union's resources behind its laid off St. Louis members, employes of three newspapers involved in a carriers' union strike.

The end of the war has brought no diminution in the demand for housing in the metropolitan area, and the reports of sales in Bergen County and other parts of New Jersey emphasized the shortage of offerings.

Stripped to an austerity basis during the war, the well cushioned services showered on shoppers by department stores will stage a lagging, closely scrutinized comeback with many frills eliminated, it was disclosed in retail store circles here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--To Secure itself against attack, the United States must maintain a large enough Navy, with sufficient bases, to control the entire Pacific, Admiral R. S. Edwards, Deputy Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, and Rear Admiral

IN 1929 Dr. Alexander Fleming, bacteriologist at St. Mary's Hospital, London, published an account of the remarkable antibacterial effects of cultures of the mold penicillin.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 25 (AP)-- Ten members of a court-martial board at the Topeka Army Air Field today found Capt. Donald L. Salisbury of Madison, N. J., guilty of manslaughter and ordered him confined at hard labor for five years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25-All wartime controls over local bus, trolley, coach and street-car service will be lifted next Friday.
ATLANTA, Aug. 25--Thirty-one leading department stores of the Sixth Federal Reserve District reported sales last week 13 per cent under the corresponding period of a year ago. For the four weeks...

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 25-- With a last-minute surge, the Columbia varsity crew swept ahead of the Princeton junior varsity shell today and crossed the finish line twelve feet in advance. The Princeton varsity was last in the triangular race, a length and a half behind the leader.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)-- Instructions for the mailing of Christmas packages to Army and Navy personnel overseas were announced today through the Office of War Information.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 25 (AP)-- Pilots who usher ships into the country's principal ports will return to civilian status after Nov. 30, the Navy Department announced today.
The Fairways Apartments, a housing property at Pelham Manor, in Westchester County, has been purchased by Fareed N. Kiamie, New York merchant and large investor in loft buildings in Manhattan.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Van Wyck Wickes Loomis of this place have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Elizabeth Mason, to Lieut. Robert

LONDON, Aug. 25--Germany's 50,000-ton luxury liner Europa, which is now an American war prize, was commissioned today as a United States Navy transport at Bremerhaven, it was announced by United States naval force headquarters in London.

ABOARD ADMIRAL McCAIN'S FLAGSHIP, off Tokyo, Aug. 25 (U.P.)--Flying an errand of mercy through flakless skies, a great parade of American planes from Vice Admiral John S. McCain's Task Force 38 dropped bundles of food and medicine to Allied prisoners of war in the Tokyo area at dawn today.

Victory in the Pacific brought last week several indications that the real story of "the day which will live in infamy"--Dec. 7, 1941--may soon be made public. The Navy announced that its files on Pearl Harbor would not be opened "until negotiations with Japan are an accomplished fact"--which was taken to mean they would be opened

The Portuguese Minister of War has ordered the lifting of war restrictions, including censorship, throughout Portugal and her colonies, the Lisbon radio said last night in a domestic broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission. Passengers will now be allowed to go ashore in transit in the Azores, on which the Allies had war bases, according to the broadcast.

One of the keenest controversies since the start of price regulation is expected to reach its climax on Tuesday in Washington when leading retail interests of the country will present their case on the issue of cost-absorption in retail reconversion pricing of consumer durable goods, it was reported here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Three big questions have arisen in China as the result of the smouldering friction between the Chinese Communists and the Central Government that now, on the eve of the long and anxiously awaited expulsion of the Japanese from China's ancient soil, is threatening to flame into civil war.

WELLINGTON, Aug. 25--New Zealand is facing a lend-lease crisis of a reverse kind because the next four months continue to hold demands for material aid for United States forces deployed in the Pacific, whereas American shipments here are expected to be greatly reduced.

WHEN Henry Canby was a student at Yale, his mother (she had been a Seidel) gave him five dollars always to sign his full name, and he has been Henry Seidel Canby ever since. Seidels, Canbys, Tatnalls,
In the years at hand this country will hear an uncommon amount of sawing and hammering and will see a great number of houses built. For a start, construction

GUATEMALA, Aug. 25--Jose Ismael Herrera and Luis Ochoa del Cid were sentenced to death today for the assassination Oct. 2, 1944, of Alejandro Cordova, member of the Guatemalan Congress and former publisher of the newspaper Imparcial.

OKINAWA, Aug. 25--Two Fifth Air Force fighter pilots, Lieut. Col. Clay Tice Jr. of Phoenix, Ariz., and Flight Officer Douglas C. Hall of Anoamosa, Iowa, became today the first Americans to have landed on Japanese soil since the cessation of hostilities.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 25 President Anastasio Somoza has announced that to guarantee justice and honesty in future elections the Secretary of the Interior would present to Congress various reforms of the present electoral law.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 25-- The rayon department of the du Pont company has made some organization changes in its nylon division, with a Wilmington nylon district sales office being created, it was announced today. P. D. Atwood will head the new office. A nylon technical service unit also has been establshed here.

The first twelve days of peace brought major changes in American life: (1) Wartime industrial and manpower controls were lifted for 85 percent of American business, according to one War Production Board source; (2) rationing of civilian goods was cut down and the promise was held out that most war-scarce items will be back on the market by the end of the year; (3) reports indicated that 1,730, 000 were newly unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)--If you have been thinking about dropping in on your old sporting goods dealer soon to buy a complete supply of new equipment, you are in for a slight shock.

MANY fathers returning from the services will be strangers to their young children; there may be a baby born since he went away, or a child then a few months old who is now talking and always under foot. Perhaps the little boy Daddy left behind him is now "Junior," going to school and acting "fresh."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 (AP) --The submarine Sealion singlehanded sank the 45,000-ton Japanese battleship Kongo off Formosa and sank the Japanese prison ship Rakuyo, from which she later rescued fifty-four Britons and Australians.
Interest in lots for one-family homes was reflected in realty activity on Long Island during the past week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Miss Barbara Beale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lewis Beale of this city, was married here this afternoon in St. Thomas' Episcopal Church to Lieut. William Hyslop Lowe Jr., USMCR, son of Mrs. Lowe of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Lowe. The Rev. Howard F. Wilkerson performed the ceremony.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25--Plans of private industry in the Northwest for reconversion to peacetime production are well organized, but governmental units apparently will move slowly in undertaking public works projects. Although more...

China, has long had grave political problems to settle. Last week the danger arose that she would try to settle them by force of arms, precipitating a crisis which would involve not only the peace of Asia but the whole world's efforts at recovery from war. At odds were the Central Government of Chungking and the Communists, of the northwest, having their capital at Yenan.

FARGE, Germany, Aug. 25 (AP) --An American tanker carrying 4,000,000 gallons of gasoline steamed twenty miles up the Weser River today and opened the United States Army's huge new gasoline depot, which will feed vehicles of the American occupation army.

THIS biography by a noted Argentine writer was first published at Buenos Aires in 1933. Its popularity throughout the Latin republics was due as much to its poetic beauty of style as to the spirited account of important historic events.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.)-- Before the reception at the French Embassy this afternoon General de Gaulle called at the White House to present gifts from Paris --a gold, bejeweled powder box for Mrs. Truman and a jewelencrusted gold watch for Miss Margaret Truman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25--Pennant hopes of the league-leading Cuba were shaken more than a little bit today when the onrushing Cardinals, gathering speed in the race down the National League stretch, won the second game of this important...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A number of textiles, fibers and such articles as military luggage made from these materials are turned back into the civilian market today as the direct result of reduced or terminated war contracts.

Stymie, bargain horse in Trainer Hirsch Jacobs' barn, proved no bargain for his three rivals in yesterday's $27,200 Saratoga Cup race at Belmont Park, for at the end of the mile and three-quarters, longest distance the turf stars have been called upon to run this season, he was a four-length winner.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 25--Miss Em Bowles Locker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Clyde Locker of this city, was married here this afternoon to Maj. Clifton Stevenson Brown of the Army, son of...

RATIONING has made most of us conscious that any excellence our cooking had before the war was not due so much to our own skill as to the wonderful materials we had in the way of fine roasts, thick cream and so on. Deprived of these things, which stood on their oivn merits, needing little help from us, we have been rather at a loss as to where to find

MANILA, Aug. 25 (U.P.)--Gen. Douglas MacArthur informed the Japanese today that they might send not more than ten reporters, photographers and newsreel men to cover the Allied landings and the surrender ceremonies, but inferentially warned them not to "scoop" American correspondents by broadcasting news dispatches in any language.

MANILA, Aug. 25 (AP)--The rector of Santo Tomas University, oldest college under the American flag, described General MacArthur as "the savior of Christian civilization and culture in the Far East" as the general received an honorary degree today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 25--The Jews, the first of many minorities to be persecuted by fascism, are finding that after three months of confusion, almost inevitable in a land so deeply scarred by war, their lot is being ameliorated in the United States...

In an expansion of its program, the New School for Social Research is to offer forty-eight courses on international affairs this fall. Many of the courses will be given by internationally known authorities.
MADRID, Aug. 25--Spain's treatment of Jewish refugees is generally good, with only isolated cases of discrimination and no evidences of actual persecution, according to relief authorities here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Moving to relieve the pressure of troop redeployment on the railroads, the War Department completed today preparations for transporting by air 30,000 soldiers a month from embarkation ports to separation centers. The new procedure will...

SUMMER resorts all over the country are already engaged in the task of getting back to normal. The return of free for-all motoring and the lifting of certain travel restrictions have brought about a sharp upswing in outdoor activities at Long Island...

PORT WASHINGTON, N. Y., Aug. 25--Poor sailing weather caused the cancellation of the special regatta scheduled at the Port Washington Yacht Club today. A fleet of twenty-nine started in the event, but lack of breeze forced all to return to the club under power.

The marriage of Miss Nathalie Livingston Hazard, daughter of Mrs. William P. Hulbert of Middleburg, Va., and the late W. Tilden P. Hazard of New York, to Howard Kaye, son of Mrs. John Turner Skinner, also of Middleburg, took place here yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. George H. Thompson performed the ceremony.

THIS is a dreamlike journey to Great Blasket Island, in the Atlantic, off the coast of Ireland's County Kerry, far from the madding crowd. We achieve, through the experience here recorded, a bountiful knowledge of peculiar persons in a peculiar place.

In mid-March, 1942; General MacArthur left Corregidor, last stronghold of American-Filipino forces in the Philippines, promising "I shall return." He put his dwindling band of "expendables" under the command of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright. A little more than a month later, on 'May 6, after a gallant defense against overwhelming odds, General Wainwright ordered the Stars and Stripes hauled down and marched off with his men to a Japanese prison camp.

We are entering a week which will display all the pageantry of victorious war without, if all goes well, any of its bloodshed. Walter P. Rutley has been elected president of the Kearny Manufacturing Company, succeeding C. F. Dulkin, who was elected chairman of the board and will continue as chief executive officer.

GUAM, Sunday, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Col. James D. Garcia, 31, and three other persons were killed at noon, Aug. 23, when their B-29 stalled a few feet off the ground in a routine check flight take-off at Harmon Field. The plane crashed and quickly burned.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25-- Several recommendations for changes in existing laws on immigration and naturalization were in prospect as a House subcommittee, headed by Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York, ended a two-day hearing in this city today.

For the last twenty years economists and social scientists have been discussing what they call "the social impact of science," and implying that legislators and business men have paid too little attention to the profound social changes brought about by revolutionary discoveries and inventions.

NOW that the green foliage of the oriental poppy is again appearing above ground, lovers of this in comparable flower will be engaged, until freezing weather halts planting, in getting additional plants into the ground, dividing old clumps and adding some of the amazing new varieties. The newcomers have three to three and one-half foot stems topped by...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)-- The Government's top housing executive says today the greatest need is a home for the man whose pocketbook can stand a payment of only $20 to $40 a month.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25--The condition of the Jews in Poland today is better than before the war in respect to their relations with the Government but worse in their relations with the people, according to the three Presidium organization of Polish Jews in the Soviet Union. This loose generality was confirmed by foreigners here who have no stake in the present Government of Poland.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 25 (AP) --An air and ground aid service has been arranged to drop medical supplies into Hong Kong tomorrow, Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's headquarters said today.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (U.P.)--Soviet troops landed on Korea's east coast today in an attempt to cut off the main body of Japan's Kwantung Army fleeing down the Korean Peninsula behind suicide rearguards.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25--Despite the victory holiday for stores in St. Louis on Aug. 15, retail trade for that week held up fairly well as against a year ago, and preliminary estimates for the succeeding week placed volume at the large...

OTTAWA, Aug. 25 (AP)--The end of gasoline rationing has boomed tourist traffic in Canada to prewar proportions. From coast to coast, steak-hungry Americans are swarming across the border to eat meat, catch fish and enjoy the scenery.
Dr. John W. Tukel of the United States Public Health service is spraying mosquitos with chemicals that make them glow in the dark so that he can find out how far they fly at night and where.

DALLAS, Aug. 25--The Texas State Highway commission this week approved a $153,000,000 highway construction program for the first three post-war years.
NEWARK, Aug. 25 (AP)--With Kari Drews yielding only five safe ties, Newark chalked up a 10-to-1 victory over Jersey City today.

MANILA, Aug. 25--As American sea forces begin the investment of Japan next week, preparatory to the formal surrender of Japan on Friday to emissaries of the major Allied Powers led by Gen. Douglas MacArthur aboard the giant battleship Missouri in Tokyo Bay, the prevailing feeling here is one uncertainty as to the future of Asia. CHESTER, N. J., Aug. 25--Miss Audrey Kay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Goddard Kay of Hidden River Farm, this place, and Palm Beach, Fla., was married to Lieut. George Allen Dines, USNR,

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 25 --Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Franz of Aimes Point, near here, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Elizabeth, to Littell Rogers Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan B. Stone of Hamden. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

Reports from all parts of the country last week told of war plant shutdowns and mass layoffs. Industrial centers of the Middle West appeared hardest hit with a total of 878,000 newly unemployed. Eastern States report some 406,000 layoffs, the West Coast and Southwest about 298,000; Southern industrial areas, 148,000.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Ann Woisard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Roland E. Woisard of Brooklyn, to George P. Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Lane, also of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents. The wedding will take place late in the autumn.

THE New Opera Company, which would seem to have outlived its name, is busy with plans for another musical, or at least so the whisper has it. The whisperer, however, seems well enough informed. For instance, although the work as yet is unchristened, the workers have been named. Marian Ainslee, an erstwhile Hollywood scenarist, and

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 25-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. L. Irwin Hartmeyer of this community of the engagement of their daughter, Gloria Bailey, to Lieut. George Henry Howard Jr., USMCR, son of Mr. Howard of New York and the late Mrs. Howard, who was Miss Elizabeth Short MacMillan.

THE future is bright for buses, but for the present they must get along with what equipment and tires are on hand or are parceled out as manufacture of supplies increases. For these reasons, despite more gasoline, the Greyhound Lines anticipate no immediate change in service, and other established bus lines admit that a general speed-up must await new equipment.

The Netherlands Government has appointed Vice Admiral C.E.L. Helfrich, commander of the Netherlands forces in the Far East, Netherland representative at the signing of the surrender terms by Japan, the Netherlands home radio announced yesterday in a broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP)--Dispatches from the Red Army front in Korea today reported the Koreans were giving the Red Army troops a rousing welcome, crowding the streets and cheering.
MR. CLARK'S novel could hardly have found a more attractive setting. It is a small Italian island in the Mediterranean, which, before the war, had been a tourist resort.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Now that the war with Japan has ended save for technicalities, and this country is at last at peace, efforts are being made to speed one of the country's greatest undertakings, the disposal of billions of dollars worth of surplus property.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 25Phyllis Otto of Atlantic, Iowa, smashed an Amazon athletic myth today when she toppled highly favored Babe Didrikson Zaharias of Los Angeles, 1 up, in one of the most thrilling title matches in women's Western amateur golf...

When the members of the House of Representatives compromised on the question of whether they should receive increased compensation or an expense allowance, the real question involved was avoided. The issue was: Why should not the members of Congress be accorded the same right of deducting their expenses, incurred while away from "home," as that granted to private business.

Stocks turned strong toward the close of last week after recovering from a sharp decline on Monday. The first full week of trading since Japan capitulated saw one of the strongest sessions in five years on last Thursday, with gains ranging from 1 to 5 points.

MANILA, Aug. 25 (AP)--Japanese Imperial headquarters notified Gen. Douglas MacArthur today that four Japanese submarines were missing and might have been sunk. Repeated efforts to communicate with them have failed, the message said. The submarines, ordered to return to Ominato, had been instructed to proceed surfaced, with all prescribed markings and using navigation lights at night, Japanese headquarters added.

F. R. VON WINDEGGER, St. Louis banker, testifying before a Senate committee on the Murray Full Employment Bill: "I have concluded that the chief qualification to be head of a bank is a constitutional inability to grasp a new idea."

RICHMOND, Aug. 25--The years of wartime prosperity have put into the treasuries of the States in this region ample funds to pay maximuim unemployment benefits to all who are likely to be thrown out of work during reconversion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--A veteran with a claim or a problem who tries to work it out for himself in dealings with the Government usually finds himself in about as helpless a position as an individual who, without a lawyer, is trying to sue a large corporation.

Dutch insurance companies are making premium payments to Jews retroactive for the entire period of German occupation, and where the insured has perished without leaving an heir payment is made to the Jewish community to which he belonged, reports the Netherlands Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.)-- One of Wake Island's greatest heroes, Comdr. Winfield S. Cunningham, has been found near Peiping, China, by a United States rescue team, the Navy said today. He had been a prisoner nearly four years.

MANILA, Aug. 25--As Gen. Douglas MacArthur's land, sea and air forces launch into the gigantic task of occupying the Japanese homeland, it appears that Japanese fanaticism which produced the Kamikaze suicide pilot must be reckoned with after the surrender.
HERE is an attempt to gather in two volumes all the available biographical material about the great nineteenth-century writer of popular songs and the other members of his family.

Selling of 10,000 to 15,000 bales of cotton in the October, 1945, position, credited to a spot house was the feature yesterday in cotton futures during the short session on the New York Cotton Exchange. This selling, in addition to scattered hedging and liquidation, influenced a reaction and final quotations were 6 to 17 points net...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The Truman Administration has demonstrated its capacity to get things through the Congress. It is now confronted with the much more difficult task of determining what it wants to get through. After four months in office, it has reached a critical time of definition when it must not only carry through the policy started by Franklin Roosevelt but decide for itself how to deal with the vast complexities of peace.

The American Arbitration Association is ready to aid Government, industry and labor in the settlement of disputes that threaten to interrupt speedy reconversion to peacetime production, Paul Fitzpatrick, vice president, stated in an interview yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 25--The situation of Italian Jews is at present identical with that of all other Italians; when that has been said, you have summed up the whole story of Benito Mussolini's abortive attempt to ape Adolf Hitler's antiSemitism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)-- Representative Jed Johnson of Oklahoma said today President Truman had accepted his invitation to attend a field artillery show at Fort Sill some time this fall. The show will be to demonstrate the part the field artillery played in the war. The President was an artillery officer in the first World War.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 25 --In one of the most enthralling matches seen on the Meadow Club courts in recent years, Alejo Russell of Buenos Aires barely man-- aged to eke out victory over Lieut. Hal Surface of Kansas City today to gain the final round of the annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament with William Talbert of Wilmington, Del.

At a meeting of chemical and mechanical engineers held earlier in the year in New York. Dr.G. C. Furnas, director of research for the CurtissWright Corporation, answered three major questions that are now asked about the commercial airplane of the post-war world. They are: How big? How fast? How many?

CHUNGKING, Sunday, Aug. 28 (U.P)--The Central News Agency reported from Chihkiang that seven transport planes carrying Lieut. Gen. Leng Hsin, Deputy Chief of Staff, and 159 officers and men arrived in Nanking today to establish forward echelon Army headquarters.

TWO-HANDED, ceremonial samurai swords, relics of the militarist traditions of feudal Japan, hung precisely at the sides of each of the military members of the Japanese surrender mission when they debarked at Manila to confer with General of the Army MacArthur.

With Arnold S. Denker, national champion; Samuel Reshevsky, former champion, and Reuben Fine, invincible as a speed artist, heading the United States team, there is no reason for misgivings as to the outcome of the forthcoming match by radio on ten boards with Soviet opponents.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)--A laundry chute loosed a shower of $20, $50 and $100 bills along with the soiled clothes today when Mrs. Cleota Atwood pulled open the chute outlet in her basement. The money--$1,920 of it-disappeared last week from a strong box belonging to a guest of the Atwoods. Police believe that the thief became uneasy over the search being conducted for the missing money and dropped it down the chute.

The body of Donald Zimmerman, 14 years old, apparently the victim of a bizarre experiment, was found last night wedged in the refrigerator in the apartment he occupied with his mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. William D. Keveney, at 1501 Metropolitan Avenue, a unit of Parkchester in the Bronx.

When President Roosevelt first proposed lend-lease in 1940, he made a striking analogy: "Suppose my neighbor's house catches fire," he said, "and I have a length of garden hose. What do I do? I don't say to him, 'Neighbor, my garden hose cost me $15; you have to pay me $15 for it.'

FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 25 --Detroit's American League pennant hopes got another boost today when Fort Meade officials announced that Tommy Bridges, 38-year-old pitching star, would be discharged from service tomorrow.

Merger of Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., and the Republic Pictures Corporation with the Setay Company, Inc., which thereafter would be known as the Republic Pictures Corporation, will be voted upon by stockholders of Consolidated Film at a special meeting on Sept. 28, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--With the end of the Pacific war, the United Nations' Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is proceeding rapidly with its procurement program for relief in China, Roy F. Hendrickson, Acting Director General, announced today.

District Attorney George J. Beldock of Kings County instituted an investigation yesterday before the grand jury to find out why members of the staff of his predecessor, William O'Dwyer, failed to seek grand jury action on twentyeight election fraud cases that had been pending in the Democratic prosecutor's office since Dec. 28, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)-- Chairman May of the House Military Affairs Committee said today that he favored a moratorium on fill drafting during September, October and November, after receiving a letter from President Truman recommending the continued induction of 18 through 25 year old men for two years of service.

PARIS, Aug. 27--Efforts by the French to protect their own reviving film industry at the expense of American films have caused a deadlock in Franco-American film negotiations and raised the possibility that no American films will enter France during the current film year, which runs until July, 1946, Harold L. Smith of the Hays office said today in an interview with a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- Chicken restrictions were lifted in twenty-one States today, with the Army returning to buy in the open market and the Department of Agriculture promising "substantially increased chicken supplies for civilian consumption."

The present plans for the peacetime Navy, as disclosed yesterday by Secretary James Forrestal, envisage a force of 500,000 men and 58,000 officers, with 400 combat ships in operation and 800 in the reserve fleet.

The three-story store and apartment building at 263 South Orange Avenue, in Newark, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to Edward Frank through Popper Brothers, brokers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)-- Practically all controls, except on prices, were lifted today on distribution and sale of fresh and processed citrus fruits.
LONDON, Aug. 27--Viscount Wavell, Viceroy of India, began his talks on Indian problems with Lord Pethick-Lawrence, Secretary of State for India, and with other officials at the India Office today.

Rules imposing restraints upon floor trading were adopted yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange directly after the Securities and Exchange Commission had agreed to give them a tryout.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--A sharp Governmental slash in the price clothmakers must pay for American wool--perhaps running as high as 15 to 20 per cent and possibly becoming effective within the next forty-eight hours--was predicted today in authoritative Boston wool trading circles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)-- A group of business men today called for immediate use of Federal funds to get jobless war workers moved to where they can get jobs.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27--The Giants elbowed their way a little closer to that highly-coveted third place slot in the National League flag race tonight as they polished off Ben Chapman's Phillies in both ends of a double-header, to the great discomfiture of 9,877 onlookers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--The aircraft carrier Enterprise, six times "sunk" by Japanese propaganda and fifteen times actually damaged by Japanese fire, received a special salute today from the Navy Department as "the fightingest carrier in the Fleet," as she lay at anchor and at peace in Puget Sound Navy Yard with workmen walking her decks. It was a final "well done" for a war now ended.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP)--Fighting from behind after wasting an early lead, the Browns won their fifth straight game from the White Sox tonight, 8 to 7, to pull within four games of the league-leading Tigers.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27--The press is publishing reports and rumors that the Government intends to introduce legislation during the coming session of Parliament making Canadian and not British the legal nationality of the people of this Dominion and substituting for the Union Jack a national flag.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 27 --From a multitude of costly postwar construction projects in Westchester County emerged today one variety that seems likely to be first in starting. It covers eradication of slums and development of low-rent apartments, with the State lending the money for land acquisition and building construction.

Rent controls will be kept at least through next June, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday as it informed tenants that they could not be evicted for refusal to sign lease renewals containing an escalator clause.

Investment funds poured yesterday into the stock market in everincreasing force as the industrial shares pushed to the highest levels since September, 1939. NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP)-- Scoring once in the seventh, Newark turned back Syracuse for the fourth straight game tonight, 3-2, stretching their winning streak to eight frames.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 29--All forms of wartime censorship have been ended and the Government is complying fully with the Act of Chapultepec. Guatemala is enjoying complete freedom of the press after many years of censorship.

BERLIN, Aug. 29--American military-government authorities in Berlin today ordered removed all so-called house and street leaders or supervisors in the American zone on the ground that they perpetuated the spirit of nazism.
Lauritz Melchior, Metropolitan Opera tenor, will return next month to his native Denmark for the first time since the war began in Europe.

Japan took the first step to insure freedom of the press and assembly yesterday when the Cabinet decided to remove various wartime restrictions on the nation's political activities, Domei Agency said in a dispatch to the American zone.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 29 --The negotiations here for settlement of the differences between the Communists and the Central Government will be pushed to a conclusion as soon as possible, Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh told a press conference here today.

ADMIRAL HALSEY'S FLAGSHIP, Tokyo Bay, Aug. 29--The United States flag that Commodore Perry flew on his mission to open trade with Japan ninetytwo years ago was delivered to Admiral Halsey's Third Fleet today for unfurling on another historic occasion--Japan's formal surrender on Sunday.

Musical horns that play the opening bars of "The Sidewalks of New York" will sound again in the Bronx Zoo today with the resumption of Zoo tours on the tractor trains acquired in 1940 from the World's Fair. Because of the gasoline shortage the cars have not been in use since the fall of 1942.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP)--Berlin women outnumber men by 69 per cent, the Russian-controlled official newspaper the Berliner Zeitung, said today. It said that a mid-August census had shown a total Berlin population of 2,784,000, compared with 4,332,000 in May, 1939. There are now 1,035,000 men and 1,748,000 women in the city.

Cohen to London with him as advisers at the meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, that will start negotiating the European peace treaties on Sept. 18.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP)--The "displaced person" is on his way to becoming an extinct species.

MADRID, Aug. 29--As American installations and technical equipment at the Baracas airfield here near completion, the status of twenty to thirty German nationals employed by the Spanish Government as aviation technicians, is receiving considerable attention.

PREAKNESS, N.J., Aug. 29-- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont and Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia turned in identical cards of 37, 40--77 to tie for the qualifying medal today in the North Jersey Country Club's golden anniversary invitation tournament.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 29 (AP) --The Syrian National Congress, youth organizations and Communists have demanded that foreign troops be withdrawn now that hostilities have ceased. [British troops are the principal forces left in Syria, which still technically is a French mandate from the League of Nations.]

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)--Busher, 3-year-old queen of the nation's fillies, gained revenge and a $25,000 check in defeating Durazna, 4 years old, by three-quarters of a length in a match race at Washington Park today. They carried equal weight of 115 pounds.

PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP)--Thirty-five Frenchmen with names such as "Andy the Baker" and "Lou Lou" were arrested today by police investigating a counterfeit racket involving hundreds of millions of francs. France has been flooded with spurious 1,000 franc notes.

The post-war aviation industry will decline to about a fifth of its war-time size, E. E. Wilson, president of the Aircraft Industries Association and vice-chairman of the United Aircraft Corporation, said last night.

The mercury climbed to 88.8 degrees at 4:15 P. M. yesterday to come within 1.2 degrees of the record for the date, established at 90 on Aug. 29, 1926. The afternoon reading represented a rise of exactly 20 degrees from the day's low, which was 68.8 at 7:45 A. M.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 (U.P.) --Senator Thomas C. Hart, former Pacific Fleet commander, said today that "a salient fact which the public doesn't understand" is that "responsibility for defense against any attack upon such a place as Pearl Harbor" rested with the Army and not with the Navy.
RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 29-- Governor Dewey discarded formality today to enjoy the sights at the Dutchess County Fair with Mrs. DeweyY and their two sons, Thomas E. Jr., 13, and John M., 9.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)-- The United States, British and Canadian Governments announced tonight that they would continue operations of the Combined Production and Resources, Raw Materials and Food Boards to handle "critical supply" problems of immediate importance.

ATHENS, Aug. 29 (Reuter)-- John Passalides, general secretary of the Socialist party, was wounded at a political meeting in Verria, Macedonia, it was learned today. The Communist newspaper Rizospastis attributed the incidents to "reactionaries concentrated at the meeting place by a British officer.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 29 (AP)-- Further reports today put the hurricane damage along the central Texas coast at more than $20,000,000. The storm was dying out in the central Texas hills.

The one-story "taxpayer" at 1002 Bay Ridge Avenue, Brooklyn, containing four stores, has been purchased by Anthony D'Esposito from the estate of Katherine G. Follert.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) --Jeff Davis, king of the hoboes' union, dropped off here and advised kids not to be hoboes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29-- "Soldier's Wife," the Rose Franken play which opened at the John Golden Theatre last October financed by M-G-M, will be produced as a film for that company by George Haight. Eddie Buzzell will direct.

PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP)--A French transport will sail from Marseille for Indo-China Sept. 5 with 800 troops and 3,000 tons of food and technical equipment, the newspaper Parisien Libere said today. The article said 8,000 troops of the French Expeditionary Corps in Madagascar had been alerted to sail for Indo-China Sept. 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 29--The Army Air Forces Redistribution Station No. 1 here will be vacated by Nov. 1 or earlier, it was announced today by Col. A. W. Snyder, commanding officer. The closing order conforms with the Nov. 15 deadline set by Acting Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson for the release of Armyoccupied hotels in this and other cities.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 29-- Garwood Ferguson, for thirty years engineer for Passaic County, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 315 East Thirty-fourth Street this city, after a long illness. He would have been 69 years old today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 29 --The Hungarian general elections, which were to have taken place next month, have, like the Bulgarian elections, been postponed.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 29-- Wheat, ships and equipment like machine tools, agricultural implements and dredges to clear the ports are what France needs most from Canada, Gen. Charles de Gaulle said here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The Army Air Forces believes it will be possible to reduce the projected "interim" Air Force of about 700,000 men by approximately 15 per cent and creating a force which will be nearer the 600,000 mark, an AAF spokesman said today.

ROME, Aug. 29 (AP)--Three Fascists convicted of murdering Italian patriots were executed at Rovido yesterday, a report reaching here said today. They were shot in the back by a firing squad. They were identified as Antonio Rinaldi, Francesco Santacroce and Isidoro Russante.

This increased the number of cases this year to ninety-eight, four of which have resulted in death. During a comparable period last year there were 147 cases, four of which resulted in death.

With various cross currents in conditions surrounding the cotton market and with little in the routine news to guide traders, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday over modest ranges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (U.P.)-- President Truman today asked the Army for particulars in the case of an Indiana soldier sentenced to die in Europe for murder.
Steel operations this week are scheduled at 74.9 per cent of capacity, against 74.5 per cent last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Tami Mauriello, one of the leading contenders for Sgt. Joe Louis' heavyweight title, registered his fourth consecutive knockout, when he floored Johnny White last night in the feature bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at the Queensboro Arena.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 4--The presence of a bottle of liquor on his person and the absence of any money in his pockets helped to clear Sigrud Meling of 87 Buena Vista Avenue, in City Court today, of suspicion of a burglary he had not committed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4--The Philadelphia Registration Commission reported today that the Republican supplementary enrollment for the November municipal elections was more than double that of the Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--Secretary Byrnes called today for a unified intelligence service of the State, War and Navy Departments and said that "the story of Pearl, Harbor" might have been different had this been the case on Dec. 7, 1941.

WEST SAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 4--The manpower shortage, which was a major factor in halving the nation's normal oyster harvest in 1944 and 1943, is easing here to such an extent that within a month the oyster industry may be producing at a rate approaching that of pre-war years, it was reported today.

NANKING, Sept. 3 (Delayed)-- The Americans in Nanking live and work in an armed Japanese camp. The Japanese garrison of more than 50,000 has not surrendered and is still in effective military control of the city.

Expansion of international trade on a cooperative basis will be pushed at the meeting of the International Cooperative Alliance to be held in London beginning on Monday and continuing through next week, it was stated here yesterday by Murray Lincoln, president of the Cooperative League of the United States of America, and general manager of the Ohio Farm Bureau Cooperatives.

Survey of the supply of filament yarn and staple fiber available to them has led rayon weavers to conclude that the return of a free market in rayon textiles will not be possible until the second quarter of 1946, according to rayon textile men yesterday.

A well-rounded display of fall and winter ready-to-wear was presented yesterday at Bloomingdale's. Showings to Green Room customers will be held from 2 to 4 o'clock weekday afternoons through Sept. 14.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--The United States will go on publishing its wartime blacklist of foreign business firms, Administration officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP)-- The Government is shooting at an employment goal of 14,000,000 people in factory jobs in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--In a farewell statement today Secretary of War Stimson warned this country not to throw away its preeminent world position by shirking the burden of maintaining sufficient military and naval strength and called for "an attitude of trust and frankness on our part toward all nations working for collective security."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--President Truman gave assurances today in a statement stressing his personal interest in the problem that the discharge of men from the armed forces was not being unduly delayed, but he warned that we could not know before next spring what our future needs for occupation and other forces would be.

The New York Port of Embarkation issued yesterday the following forecast of ships and military unit arrivals, printed here with the warning that dates and even the port of arrival may be changed. Port officers requested relatives of returning troops not to attempt to meet the ships, but to stay at home awaiting messages from men coming in.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 19 --Women workers in this city, who constituted almost one-third of the labor force in local plants during the war, were among the first to be laid off immediately after V-J Day and are now being met with answers of "no women being hired" and "we don't want women" when they apply to company employment offices for peacetime jobs.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP)--One little Texas League single was all today that kept big Bob Feller from making a second appearance among baseball's no-hit pitchers as he hurled the Indians to a 2-0 victory over Detroit to trim the Tigers' American League lead over the idle Senators to one game.

The State Department of Labor and the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission discovered yesterday that the reconversion unemployment situation in New York City was not so serious as might have been expected.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 19--United States occupation forces in the American area of Korea have revoked six restrictive Japanese laws that for years denied Koreans the right of free religious worship, free speech and freedom of the press, as well as freedom from persecution for political activity.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 19-- The football season starts on Saturday for Syracuse in Archbold Stadium and Head Coach Ossie Solem and his aides are pretty much in the dark as to what to expect from the squad they have been whipping into shape.

UNION CITY, N. J., Sept. 23-- The local scholastic football season got under way here today when St. Peter's, Prep smothered Bayonne Tech, 39--0. Marty Nesbitt and Bill Villa, a substitute, each tallied a pair of touchdowns.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP)--The red light of danger is flashing along the highways, with millions of motorists, released from wartime restraints, wheeling into their most perilous period.

TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP)--A young naval radioman reported today that he had wandered around central Hokkaido for sixty-eight days after his plane had crashed, raiding root cellars and hencoops and milking cows for sustenance, and that he did not learn until Sept. 19 that the war had been over for more than a month.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 23 (UP)-- American military leaders appealed today to Korean workers to end an unorganized walkout, started partly as a celebration, that began with Japan's surrender and has brought manufacturing south of the 38th paralled, dividing line between the Russian and American occupation zones, virtually to a standstill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Reconversion from a war economy to a peace economy will cause a drop of about $8,000,000,000 in individual incomes during the second half of 1945, bringing the year's total to the 1944 level of income payments, Secretary of Commerce Henry A. Wallace said today.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week was quiet. The Canadian free dollar which had absorbed the major interest of traders in the preceding weeks because of its wide fluctuations settled down to a narrow price range on a minimum of turnover. LONDON, Sept. 23--Thomas Burke, the novelist and essayist, who was noted for prowling in the strange places of his native London to absorb atmosphere for his books, died here yesterday at the age of 59.

Mayor La Guardia closed his radio broadcast yesterday with a little drama of his own--the swearing in of Arthur W. Wallander as Police Commissioner. ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP)--The State Post-war Public Works Planning Commission announced today its approval of sixty more applications for projects in thirty-eight up-State communities, at an estimated cost of $9,894,570. Joe Governale and Johnny Ryan, middleweights, will perform in the feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove Sports Club, Brooklyn, on Saturday night. Their clash is scheduled for eight rounds. Another eight-rounder will bring together Ruby Keesler and Tommy Mills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The offering through the Federal Reserve Bank of 7/8 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series H-1946, open on an exchange basis, par for par, to holders of Series G-1945 certificates maturing on Oct.1, 1945, was announced tonight by Secretary of the Treasury Vinson. George W. Romney, general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, drew a bright picture of the outlook for that industry in an address before the National Industrial Conference Board. Reconversion is proceeding more rapidly than had been anticipated.

LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP)--The Cardinals hammered four Red pitchers for 12 hits in a free-scoring 9-to-6 victory over their Nemesis, Cincinnati, today to keep pace with the league-leading Cubs and a chance to take over the top rung when they meet the Bruins in a two-game series next Tuesday and Wednesday.

Plugging the sale of tickets for two musical events this week in his broadcast over WNYC yesterday, Mayor La Guardia told his listeners how much he likes Beethoven's Ninth symphony, which is to be given tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall as a benefit by the NBC Orchestra with Arturo Toscanini conducting.

Roth the assets and business formerly owned by Mechanical Foundries, Inc., at Vernon, Calif. A total of $55,188,000 in civil engineering construction for the week in the United States was reported yesterday by Engineering News-Record, which said it represented a 187 per cent increase over the $19,235,000 in the corresponding week of 1944, but was slightly blow the $60,389,000 total for last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation indicated today that the year-end may bring a reduction in insurance premiums for the 14,000 banks covered by insurance, and possibly an extension of coverage.

HAMILTON FIELD, Calif., Sept. 28--President Sergio Osmena of the Philippines arrived here today on his way to Washington for a conference with President Truman.

Louis Schleifer, who bought the old Broadway Central Hotel at 667-77 Broadway, near Third Street, from Minnie Manischewitz, wife of the matzoh manufacturer, last month, has resold it to Henry Goelet, a realty operator.

Three fillies, topped by the Maine Chance Farm's undefeated Beaugay, queen of her division, and eleven colts, headed by Dr. Eslie Asbury's Revoked, have been named overnight for the fifty-sixth running of the $25,000 added Futurity, the world's most famous stake for juveniles, at Belmont Park ttoday.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 28--Mrs. Richard Hellmann'of Scarsdale won her second successive low-gross victory in Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association competition today by carding 42--42--84 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

BOSTON, Sept. 28--Two years ago Boston College was ready to throw in the sponge and give up football until the war ended. With the student enrollment dwindling almost to the vanishing point and lacking a Navy unit to furnish the manpower, the college authorities were convinced that there was no possible chance of fielding a varsity.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 28 (U.P.)--Five American sailors have died and several others have suffered serious illness as a result of drinking poisoned liquor sold by small bars, mostly in the Hongkew area. Two other United States sailors were drowned in the Wangpoo River, but both deaths were described as accidental. There were no reports of assaults or robbery.

ALBANY, Sept. 28--The State Banking Department announced today its approval of an increase of capital stock of the Bank of Smithtown, at Smithtown Branch. The increase is from $100,000, consisting of 1,000 shares of common stock, par value $100 each, to $150,000 composed of 1,500 shares of the same par value.

LUENEBURG, Sept. 28 (U.P.)-- Dr. Fritz Leo, who practiced medicine in Dresden before he became a victim of the Nazis, told in detail today how inmates of Belsen concentration camp resorted to cannibalism to avoid starvation.

There was a marked increase in the dollar volume of construction contracts awarded in metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey in August, and civil engineering construction volume throughout the country last week was the highest since July 15, 1943.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)--Montgomery Ward Co. said today that R.S. Stevens had announced his resignation as vice president, general merchandise manager and as a director. No reason for the resignation was announced.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 28--The Rumanian situation has developed a double aspect with King Michael's insistence on the resignation of the Groza Cabinet paralleled by a reported rift between Premier Petru Groza and the Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, George Tatarescu.
LONDON, Sept. 28--Allied participation in the occupation of Japan continued today to play one of the most important roles in the efforts of the Council of Foreign Ministers to reach some agreements.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 28-- The Bolivian Government decided today to break diplomatic and commercial relations with the Spanish Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Office of Price Administration announced today "profit factors" by which reconverting manufacturers of nine types of consumer and industrial goods may compute their new ceiling prices.

IF intercollegiate halfbacks ever fumbled the ball as often as the Cubs and the Tigers have fumbled their pennant chances in the past month, the coaches would have banished them to the junior varsity long ago. Be that as it may, however, the baseball season officially ends tomorrow, while the football campaign formally begins today despite some sporadic preliminary firing last week.

The Cross Company of Detroit filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 60,000 shares of $10 par value 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock. F.H. Koller , Co., Inc., was named as the underwriter.

Football, which got its foot inside the door in its bid for recognition from the sports fans a week ago, is certain to go all the way today when most of the country's leading elevens swing into action.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 28 (AP)--Reports that natives were eating only every second day to conserve their meager stocks of food came out of the northern Transvaal today as South Africa sweltered in a drought that in some districts was termed the worst in eighty years.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28--The Secretary of Communications was quoted today in Excelsior as saying that Mexico would adopt a free enterprise policy in regard to the establishment of new national air routes. Sunshine in Washington Square brought joy yesterday to artists who assembled oil paintings and water-colors for public approval in the outdoor fall exhibit sponsored by the Washington Square Association. The display will continue, daily and Sunday in good weather, through Oct. 14.
TOKYO, Sept. 28--Home sailing dates for three divisions in addition to the Forty-third Infantry Division, which already was loading at Yokohoma, were announced today.

SALEM, N.Y., Sept. 28--Governor Dewey, expressing fear that the London Conference of Allied Foreign Ministers may be progressing "unsatisfactorily," said today that enduring peace can be achieved only by "sacrifice and compromise."
BERLIN, Sept. 28 (AP)--A veteran of the old Sixth Cavalry Regiment said today that 135 of its men were secretly flown to the Bahamas in 1942 to help keep order during labor troubles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--President Truman, in a surprise move today, nominated for Solicitor General J. Howard McGrath, now serving his third term as Governor of Rhode Island.

Although broiling has long been accepted as the simplest, quickest and neatest way to cook a fish, a standard method of going about it has never been determined. Cookbooks disagree as to temperature, time and other directions, with the result that there is a vast difference between one person's broiled fish and another's.

United States Attorney John F.X. McGohey filed ten criminal informations in Federal Court yesterday charging a corporation and ten individuals with the sale of nearly two million yards of finished cotton and rayon piece goods above ceiling prices fixed by the Office of Price Administration.

Compared with August, 1944, when inspections were 22,262,870 feet, the total was off 1.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The mounting oil strike crisis was discussed by the Cabinet at its meeting today, where it was reported that continuing curtailment of the output of the closed refineries would affect the Army and Navy's program of deployment and transportation of veterans from the former war theatres.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- A C-54 winged away from the Washington National Airport today, starting a round-the-world flight on a regular, timetable basis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Miss Priscilla Wood Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Darius Perry of this city, was married here tonight to Dr. William Hutchinson Sprunt 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. W.H. Sprunt of Winston-Salem, N.C., in St. Mary's Chapel of the Washington Cathedral. The Rev. Dr. J. Hillman Hollister of the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP)--After a lull of almost four years, Sal Bartolo, 130 , of Boston, the N.B.A.'s featherweight titlist, squared his accounts with Maxie Shapiro, 133 , New York veteran, by gaining a unanimous decision in their sixth clash, a ten-round feature boxing bout in the Boston Garden.
SEATTLE, Sept. 28--Ralph V. M. Gorsline, a key witness in the Hall-Mills murder trial in New Jersey, died here Tuesday night in the Madison Street Hospital. His age was 66.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright was named today as commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command, with headquarters on Governors Island, New York City, the War Department announced.

As part of the "people's campaign" to unseat the military dictatorship ruling Argentina, a new type of general strike will be called by labor, business and professional groups, according to four union leaders who arrived here from Buenos Aires Thursday en route to the World Trade Union Conference in Paris.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 28--The need for an active consumer consciousness as a means of stabilizing our economy and thus establishing higher standards of living was stressed by speakers at an allday institute on consumer problems sponsored by the New Jersey division of the American Association of University Women at Essex House here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28--First Lieut. Lester R. Nahouse of Rutherford, N.J., navigator of a B-29 bomber, was killed on Sept. 2 in an aircraft accident at Guam, according to a message from the War Department. He was a brother of William O. Nahouse of White Plains.

With war time ending at 2 A.M. tomorrow, most citizens were expected to turn their clocks back one hour tonight before retiring, regaining the hour of sleep lost when war time went into effect on Feb. 9, 1942.

LONDON, Sept. 28--The Big Three Foreign Ministers met once again and failed once again today to solve the procedural impasse that by mutual agreement is staving off further discussion of eastern European problems at the Allied council here.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 28-- Surging from behind in the closing minutes of the game, Army's junior varsity football team successfully launched its 1945 campaign tripping the Barksdale Field Skyraiders, 13 to 8, in a spirited contest today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28-- The Buffalo, Niagara Eastern Power Corporation's reorganization plan and the company's consolidation with three of its subsidiaries will be approved, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today, providing six commission-suggested modifications are made in the plan within thirty days.

PARIS, Sept. 28--Circulation of French currency continues to rise according to the Bank of France statement issued today for date of Sept. 13. It increased 4,308,000,000 francs for the week, reaching a total of 483,617,000,000.

LONDON, Sept. 28--Announcing a five-point program to be carried out over the coming years, the Central Institute of Art and Design announced today that it would give substance to Britain's effort to be the center of fine and industrial arts.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 28 (AP)--Walter W. Bacon, Governor of Delaware, is recuperating from a minor operation at the Delaware Hospital here. His condition today was reported as good.
BERLIN, Sept. 28 (U.P.)--Pastor Martin Niemoeller's second son, Hermann, has returned to his father's home in Berlin after more than two years of military service in Russia, it was disclosed today.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 28--Concentrated toxoid for treatment of arthritis victims, a process for the production of the rare sugar D-ribose, and a number of developments in plastics and synthetic rubber were among the 444 inventions to receive patents at the United States patent office here during the week.
R.R. Fisher has been appointed New York district manager of the De Soto Division of Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The American Federation of Labor has won its fight to have its spokesman named as the chief workers' delegate to the coming conference of the International Labor Organization in Paris.

The twenty-second annual Women's International Exposition which will be geared this year to "Woman's Life in peacetime" will be held at Madison Square Garden Nov. 13 to 18, it was announced yesterday by Exposition officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Dr. Charles Whitney Gilmore, curator of the department of vertebrate paleontology at the National Museum, died here yesterday after an illness of several weeks. His age was 71.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)--The world's first futures trading market in frozen dressed poultry will be established Monday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, it was announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 28--A subcommittee of the United Nations Executive Committee recommended today that the host State of the headquarters of the new organization provide guarantees and facilities similar to those that were afforded the League of Nations by Switzerland and that the headquarters and most of divisions associated with it be situated at the same place.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28-- Fred MacMurray has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the romantic lead opposite Ida Lupino in the forthcoming murder thriller, "The Dark Corner." PRAGUE, Sept. 28 (AP)--The Ninety-fourth Division's hefty football team beat the Twenty-second Corps squad, 6 to 0, today in a game which was a football lesson to 40,000 Prague citizens in Masaryk Stadium.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his deputy, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, are expected to pay a one-day visit to The Hague and Amsterdam on Oct. 6. Frank C. Rathje, vice president of the American Bankers Association, was elected yesterday president for 1945-46 to succeed W. WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP)-- President Truman has set Nov. 15 as the official date for the end of the Office of Censorship. The order also ended the Censorship Policy Board as of today. The office lifted all censorship restrictions Aug. 16, two days after Japan agreed to surrender.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- The Federal Government expects soon to relinquish control of properties seized from Montgomery Ward Co. in December.

The board of directors of American Export Airlines, Inc., voted yesterday to change the company's name to American Airline Overseas, Inc., reflecting its affiliation with American Airlines earlier this year.

The election of Henry S. Morgan as a director of the General Electric Company was announced yesterday after a board meeting held here. A partner in Morgan Stanley Co., Mr. Morgan previously served as a director of GE from November, 1935, to September, 1941, when he resigned to enter the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- President Truman proclaimed today the Federal right of control and jurisdiction of minerals in the off-shore ocean floor out to a depth of 600 feet and asserted the Government rights to control ocean fishing water contiguous to the United States.

The Transport Workers Union, which has threatened to strike against the Fifth Avenue Coach Company on the issue of one-man operation of the company buses, announced yesterday that meetings had been called for next Monday and Tuesday to decide the next step in the dispute of the drivers with the company.
Dr. John L. Corish, for fifty years a physician in Brooklyn and Queens, died Thursday in his home at 102-26 134th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, after a brief illness. His age was 80.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Senator Donnell, Republican, of Missouri, told the Senate today that there was no basis for President Truman to say the Senate let him down in not approving the Administration's jobless pay bill. The six-story apartment building at 570 West 204th Street, accomodating eighty-nine families, has been acquired by Lusol Estates, Inc., headed by David Fromhartz. The property is assessed at $315,000. Jack S. Glasser was attorney for the buyer and Levy, Murphy Stolz acted for the seller.

Dr. James Foster Hatbrouck, retired New York oral surgeon specializing in extraction, who, for many years, had the largest practice in that field of any dentist in this city, died last Saturday at his home in Pasadena, Calif., according to word received here last night. He was 75 years old.
